@crimkadid Protected by the English Channel, the English enjoyed more peace than the Continentals so they less needed to study the blade and could devote more hours to playing militarily useless games like cricket.

@crimkadid Can you imagine a sports convention in the Ottoman Empire trying to come up with fair rules for everybody? It would devolve into Kurds screaming at Armenians that their proposed offside rule was obviously a devious Armenian conspiracy to cheat Kurds.

@crimkadid The English were more ruled nationally rather than feudally since the 900s, so they were inclined to come up with national solutions for the diversity of sports rules once railways finally made that important.

@crimkadid The Brits in Argentina don't argue over whether you can pick up the football. Instead, they have one sport, rugby, where everybody does, and a different sport, soccer, where nobody does. So, you start learning the British rules for the type of football you prefer and spread them.

@crimkadid Say you are a 19th Century Argentine laborer building a railroad. On your day off, you want to play football, but every town in Argentina has different rules, so you argue. In contrast, the British engineers don't argue because they all know their rules, and they're good rules.

@crimkadid The territory of England has been roughly the same size since the 900s: very national rather than regional. English public schools evolved in part to ensure that next generation ruling elites all had the same national upper class accent and all knew each other growing up.

@crimkadid The main exceptions to the rise of British dominance of world sports were other British offshoot countries, such as America, Canada, and Australia. They got railways early too and could track what was evolving in England and do the same for their own local sports.

@crimkadid As the non-Anglo world later got railways, allowing teams to travel, they could either go through this laborious process of nationalizing the rules of their local sports, or just accept the well thought-out rules that English-speakers had been evolving for a generation.

@crimkadid In 1872 IIRC, English football permanently split over the insoluble question of picking up the ball and running with it. Rugby School and its allies agreed to use hands. Eton and Cambridge said no, feet only, and formed an "Association," with its game shortened to "soccer."
@crimkadid Sometimes at Victorian era conventions, sports didn't coalesce but instead split into two sports.

@crimkadid American football evolved out of rugby during the post-Civil War era at a series of post-season conventions at railroad terminal hotels, as college coaches got together annually to debate and vote to modify the rules based on what happened each season.

@crimkadid During the American Civil War, Union soldiers in Army camps played a lot of baseball, which is descended from English rounders. But everybody had their own local rules, with the most evolved being NYC's and Boston's. Eventually, NYC rules won the loyalty of Midwestern troops.

@crimkadid Every village in Europe had their own version of football, like the still existent Eton Wall Game and Ashbourne Mob Football. Anglos got railways first, allowing teams to travel, leading to conventions of team captains at railway hotels where local rules were nationalized.
